title: The surprising esports culture of Korea

replies.body:
A post with 2 responses that was put up an hour ago on a thread that is 4 days old already has a combined upvote of over 325? If this doesn't scream red flag to anyone, I don't know if anything will.

Edit: over 450 and rising in the course of 5 minutes, and it seems their downvoting me too. This is kind of funny.
korea{{item:3072}}  the rest of the world {{item:1075}}

Riot just softening the blow for the Korean Sweep

if you can read, it's talking about how esports in Korea isn't as widespread and worshiped as one would might think. sure, I thought the entire country was just like ALL ABOUT STARCRAFT n online gaming. But the niche market, subset of the population deal makes sense. Hopefully League can continue to accomplish its goals in popularizing and furthering the esports stuff. Cause by the sound of it, they're telling us it ain't easy lol... - Sincerely, Mr. SurprisedAF

Well think about it, look at how long it took for Rock n Roll to be considered "mainstream" here in America -- some of the older generation STILL don't agree with it! Rap is still just becoming mainstream, and things like Dungeons and Dragons is still considered "weird" by a majority of the population even after like 20+ years. It takes a LONG time to get an entire society behind something new.

"Rap is still becoming mainstream"

Um.... I'm almost certain amongst the youth, Rap is a very mainstream music genre, whereas Rock has fallen out to about the same standard as country music. Pop and Rap/Hiphop/R&B are the most mainstream forms of music amongst the youth.
i wouldnt put rock music in the ignored catagorie, if you look at the less viewed groups out there you will find it just about everywhere.{{champion:82}}
The only people that would find this depiction of Korean eSports culture as "surprising"  would be as interesting to have a conversation with as {{champion:33}}
Ok

"Gaming is undoubtedly an important part of Korea’s youth culture -- many students can be found spending their precious free time in “PC bangs,” or Internet cafes, primarily focused on online gaming."


I think in Africa these would create a lot of interest in esports.

Either than South Africa, the rest of the continent doesn't have the necessary infrastructure to do so.

Unlike most countries, S.Korea uses T1 connection that runs on fiber optic lines, instead of your average North American CABLE.
The hyperlink in the last paragraph is dead.

Such a beautiful country

Once you go there, there's no coming back

This is such hard bs that I'm about to puke. Live here for a while and then say that...vacation here don't count...I'm here with my wife as english teachers and the streets are filled with garbage...this country acts like a third world country still because they have risen to wealth so quickly...the social-political problems in this country are massive...two months ago someone got fired at my school for having epilepsy! Does that seem like a wonderful place to live? The older generation here are stuck in third world country mode and act extremely uneducated...so for all this education they're talking about people still act like backwards hicks...this country has shiny lights and sparkly decorations but underneath all its makeup it's actually quite ugly...try another asian country and see the difference in progressive thinking. korea is already too full of foreigners who just came here to party and pick up korean girls =_= this country is due for a giant anti foreigners backlash like they always do every few years.
